content: The "Strong Families Act" allows for an employer credit for paid family and medical leave under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Strong Families Act" provides a credit for paid family and medical leave to eligible employers. The credit is based on a percentage of wages paid to qualifying employees during family and medical leave, with a maximum limit based on the normal hourly wage. The "Strong Families Act" provides a credit for paid family and medical leave to eligible employers based on the normal hourly wage rate of the employee. The maximum amount of leave eligible for the credit is 12 weeks. The "Strong Families Act" defines an eligible employer as one who offers a policy providing at least 2 weeks of annual paid family and medical leave for full-time employees and a proportional amount for part-time employees. The "Strong Families Act" requires that the rate of payment for medical leave be at least 50 percent of the employee's normal wages. An added employer must comply with this rule. An added employer must provide paid family and medical leave in compliance with a policy that ensures no interference with employee rights or discrimination for opposing prohibited practices. The term 'employee' refers to a qualifying employee not covered by the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. An 'added employer' is an eligible employer offering paid family and medical leave to added employees. For determining paid family and medical leave, leave paid by a State or local government is not considered. Employers are not penalized for non-compliance with the requirements of this section. Qualifying employees must have worked for the employer for at least 1 year and received compensation in the preceding year. For family and medical leave, qualifying employees must have worked for the employer for at least 1 year and received compensation not exceeding 60 percent of the amount applicable for the preceding year. Leave provided under the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 for specified purposes is considered as family and medical leave, excluding paid vacation, personal, or sick leave. In subsection (3), vacation leave, personal leave, and medical or sick leave are defined as types of leave.
